maml:description.maml:para: Inserts PostgreSQL data.

maml:copyright.maml:para: Copyright (c) 2018 CData Software, Inc. - All rights reserved.

maml:description.maml:para: Inserts PostgreSQL data. The Add-PostgreSQL cmdlet allows you to use a syntax similar to SQL INSERT statements to create new PostgreSQL records.
Add-PostgreSQL -Connection $connection -Table "Orders" -Columns @("ShipCity") -Values @("Raleigh")
The columns on which the operation will be performed.
The connection object.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The values that will be used to update the table.
The columns on which the operation will be performed.
The connection object.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The values that will be used to update the table.
The unique Id of the inserted row.

command:returnValue.maml:description: The unique Id of the inserted row.

maml:description.maml:para: Closes a connection to PostgreSQL.

maml:copyright.maml:para: Copyright (c) 2018 CData Software, Inc. - All rights reserved.

maml:description.maml:para: Closes a connection to PostgreSQL The Disconnect-PostgreSQL cmdlet is used to close a connection that was opened by the Connect-PostgreSQL cmdlet.
Disconnect-PostgreSQL -Connection $connection
The connection object.
The connection object.
Searches and updates PostgreSQL data.

maml:copyright.maml:para: Copyright (c) 2018 CData Software, Inc. - All rights reserved.

maml:description.maml:para: Searches and updates PostgreSQL data. The Invoke-PostgreSQL cmdlet allows you to use SQL statements to execute any SQL statement directly. Below is the syntax for a parameterized query:
$query = Invoke-PostgreSQL -Connection $connection -Query 'SELECT * FROM Orders WHERE ShipCountry=@ShipCountry' -Params @{'@ShipCountry'='USA'}
This cmdlet is also useful for executing stored procedures. Use the EXEC keyword to call a stored procedure:
$query = Invoke-PostgreSQL -Connection $connection -Query 'EXEC SelectEntries ObjectName = @exStoredProcInput;' -Params @{"Account"'
The connection object.
The parameters that will be used for the query.
The SQL query to execute.
The connection object.
The parameters that will be used for the query.
The SQL query to execute.
The number of rows affected by the operation.

command:returnValue.maml:description: The number of rows affected by the operation.

maml:description.maml:para: The unique Id of the inserted row.

command:returnValue.maml:description: The unique Id of the inserted row.

maml:description.maml:para: The results of the query.
Deletes PostgreSQL data.

maml:copyright.maml:para: Copyright (c) 2018 CData Software, Inc. - All rights reserved.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes PostgreSQL data. The Remove-PostgreSQL cmdlet allows you to use a syntax similar to SQL DELETE statements to delete PostgreSQL data.
$conn = Connect-PostgreSQL -User 'postgres' -Password 'admin' -Server '127.0.0.1' -Port '5432' -Database 'postgres'
Remove-PostgreSQL -Connection $conn -Table "Orders" -Id "10261"
The Where parameter can also be used to specify the primary key:
Remove-PostgreSQL -Connection $conn -Table "exTable;" -Where "Id = 10261"
The primary key can also be passed to the cmdlet along the pipeline:
Select-PostgreSQL -Connection $conn -Table Orders -Where "ShipCountry = 'USA'" | Remove-PostgreSQL
The connection object.
The Id of the item on which the operation will be performed.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The SQL WHERE clause that will be used for the operation.
The connection object.
The Id of the item on which the operation will be performed.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The SQL WHERE clause that will be used for the operation.
The number of rows affected by the operation.

command:returnValue.maml:description: The number of rows affected by the operation.

maml:description.maml:para: Opens a new connection to PostgreSQL

maml:copyright.maml:para: Copyright (c) 2018 CData Software, Inc. - All rights reserved.

maml:description.maml:para: The Connect-Postgresql cmdlet is used to create a persistent connection object to be used with related cmdlets. When executing the cmdlet a connection object is returned. Pass this object to the Connection parameter of related cmdlets to use the newly created connection object. To disconnect, call Disconnect-Postgresql.
Prepare a query statement before its execution.
The name of the PostgreSQL database.
A password used to authenticate to a proxy-based firewall.
The TCP port for a proxy-based firewall.
The name or IP address of a proxy-based firewall.
The protocol used by a proxy-based firewall.
The user name to use to authenticate with a proxy-based firewall.
A path to the directory that contains the schema files defining tables, views, and stored procedures.
A path to the log file.
A string specifying the maximum size in bytes for a log file (ex: 10MB). When the limit is hit, a new log is created in the same folder with the date and time appended to the end.
Use offline mode to get the data from the cache instead of the live source.
The other parameters necessary to connect to a data source, such as username and password, when applicable.
The password required for authentication with the PostgreSQL server.
The port number of the PostgreSQL server.
Set this to true to pass the query to PostgreSQL as is.
You can use this property to enforce read-only access to PostgreSQL from the provider.
The host name or IP address of the server.
The TLS/SSL client certificate store for SSL Client Authentication (2-way SSL).
The password for the TLS/SSL client certificate.
The subject of the TLS/SSL client certificate.
The type of key store containing the TLS/SSL client certificate.
The certificate to be accepted from the server when connecting using TLS/SSL.
Restrict the tables reported to a subset of the available tables. For example: Tables=TableA,TableB,TableC.
The value in seconds until the connection timeout error is thrown.
The username used to authenticate with the PostgreSQL Server .
This field sets whether SSL is enabled.
The verbosity level that determines the amount of detail included in the log file.
Restrict the views reported to a subset of the available tables. For example: Views=ViewsA,ViewsB,ViewsC.
Prepare a query statement before its execution.
The name of the PostgreSQL database.
A password used to authenticate to a proxy-based firewall.
The TCP port for a proxy-based firewall.
The name or IP address of a proxy-based firewall.
The protocol used by a proxy-based firewall.
The user name to use to authenticate with a proxy-based firewall.
A path to the directory that contains the schema files defining tables, views, and stored procedures.
A path to the log file.
A string specifying the maximum size in bytes for a log file (ex: 10MB). When the limit is hit, a new log is created in the same folder with the date and time appended to the end.
Use offline mode to get the data from the cache instead of the live source.
The other parameters necessary to connect to a data source, such as username and password, when applicable.
The password required for authentication with the PostgreSQL server.
The port number of the PostgreSQL server.
Set this to true to pass the query to PostgreSQL as is.
You can use this property to enforce read-only access to PostgreSQL from the provider.
The runtime key used for licensing.
The host name or IP address of the server.
The TLS/SSL client certificate store for SSL Client Authentication (2-way SSL).
The password for the TLS/SSL client certificate.
The subject of the TLS/SSL client certificate.
The type of key store containing the TLS/SSL client certificate.
The certificate to be accepted from the server when connecting using TLS/SSL.
Restrict the tables reported to a subset of the available tables. For example: Tables=TableA,TableB,TableC.
The value in seconds until the connection timeout error is thrown.
The username used to authenticate with the PostgreSQL Server .
This field sets whether SSL is enabled.
The verbosity level that determines the amount of detail included in the log file.
Restrict the views reported to a subset of the available tables. For example: Views=ViewsA,ViewsB,ViewsC.
The PostgreSQL connection object.

command:returnValue.maml:description: The PostgresqlConnection object may be passed to related cmdlets to use the connection.

maml:description.maml:para: Searches PostgreSQL data.

maml:copyright.maml:para: Copyright (c) 2018 CData Software, Inc. - All rights reserved.

maml:description.maml:para: Searches PostgreSQL data. The Select-PostgreSQL cmdlet allows you to use a syntax similar to SQL SELECT statements to search PostgreSQL data.
$conn = Connect-PostgreSQL -User 'postgres' -Password 'admin' -Server '127.0.0.1' -Port '5432' -Database 'postgres'
Select-PostgreSQL -Connection $conn -Table "Orders" -Columns @("ShipName","ShipCity") -Where "ShipCountry='USA'"
The columns to return.
The connection object.
A comma-separated list of columns that the result set will be grouped by.
The order in which columns will be returned.
The parameters that will be used for the query.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The SQL WHERE clause that will be used for the operation.
The columns to return.
The connection object.
A comma-separated list of columns that the result set will be grouped by.
The order in which columns will be returned.
The parameters that will be used for the query.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The SQL WHERE clause that will be used for the operation.
The results of the query.
Syncs PostgreSQL data.

maml:copyright.maml:para: Copyright (c) 2018 CData Software, Inc. - All rights reserved.

maml:description.maml:para: Syncs PostgreSQL data. The Sync-PostgreSQL cmdlet allows you to replicate a data source locally and maintain it with the full caching functionality of the provider.
$conn = Connect-PostgreSQL -User 'postgres' -Password 'admin' -Server '127.0.0.1' -Port '5432' -Database 'postgres'
Sync-PostgreSQL -Connection $conn -Table "Orders"
The columns to sync.
The connection object.
The table where the data will be placed.
The parameters that will be used for the query.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The columns to sync.
The connection object.
The table where the data will be placed.
The parameters that will be used for the query.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The number of rows affected by the operation.

command:returnValue.maml:description: The number of rows affected by the operation.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates PostgreSQL data.

maml:copyright.maml:para: Copyright (c) 2018 CData Software, Inc. - All rights reserved.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates PostgreSQL data. The Update-PostgreSQL cmdlet allows you to use a syntax similar to SQL UPDATE statements to update PostgreSQL data.
$conn = Connect-PostgreSQL -User 'postgres' -Password 'admin' -Server '127.0.0.1' -Port '5432' -Database 'postgres'
Update-PostgreSQL -Connection $conn -Table "Orders" -Columns @("ShipCity") -Values @("Raleigh") -Id "10261"
The Where parameter can also be used to specify the primary key of the table:
Update-PostgreSQL -Connection $conn -Table "Orders" -Columns @("ShipCity") -Values @("Raleigh") -Where "Id = '10261'"
The primary key can also be passed to the cmdlet along the pipeline:
Select-PostgreSQL -Connection $conn -Table Orders -Where "ShipCountry = 'USA'" | Update-PostgreSQL -Columns @("ShipCountry") -Values @("USA 2")
The columns on which the operation will be performed.
The connection object.
The Id of the item on which the operation will be performed.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The values that will be used to update the table.
The SQL WHERE clause that will be used for the operation.
The columns on which the operation will be performed.
The connection object.
The Id of the item on which the operation will be performed.
The table on which the operation will be performed.
The values that will be used to update the table.
The SQL WHERE clause that will be used for the operation.
The number of rows affected by the operation.

command:returnValue.maml:description: The number of rows affected by the operation.
